content.webTitle: Swansea defeat allows Eddie Howe to enjoy Bournemouth’s defining moment

fields.headline: Swansea defeat allows Eddie Howe to enjoy Bournemouth’s defining moment
fields.bodyText: Who slows up in sight of the winning line? The Cheltenham Festival begins this week but that, in fact, was an inspirational quote Eddie Howe, so detailed and thorough in his preparation, delivered to his players to digest before Bournemouth brushed aside Swansea City to all but secure their Premier League status for another season. Bournemouth’s supporters must be wondering whether this fairytale will ever end, with a top-half finish now well within reach. And their maiden season in the top flight has been so absorbing for Howe, forever distant from all the hyperbole and fanfare, who admits he has struggled to take it all in. “There’s a satisfaction at the end you can look back and think that was a nice moment in hindsight but when you’re in it, at that second, there’s too much at stake to really sit back and enjoy it,” said the Bournemouth manager. “I don’t think the pressure’s ever off in football, let alone in the Premier League.” The 13-point cushion between Bournemouth and the relegation zone has, though, allowed Howe to breathe relatively easy before a tricky run of matches that includes hosting Manchester City and Chelsea. Bournemouth have put in the hard graft of late and, although hypothetical, if the season started on 1 December the Cherries would sit third in the Premier League. Their third straight win also wiped away the need to rush joint top-scorer Callum Wilson back to fitness. Wilson could return from a cruciate knee injury next month, although the striker is yet to begin training with the rest of the squad. Bournemouth are doing just fine without him at the moment. Max Gradel scored his first Premier League goal and Joshua King added his second in as many matches to twice put the Cherries in front against Swansea, who levelled before Steve Cook’s late winning header. Gradel’s last goal for the club came during a loan spell against Millwall in 2008 and it has been some journey for Bournemouth since. “It is crazy,” said Gradel, who dedicated his strike to Howe (below). “He has always been here for me. When I was on loan here I had a hard time. He was there when I lost my mother. If people are good for you, then you have to give something back to them.” Francesco Guidolin, who will return to the dugout against Aston Villa on Saturday after a lung infection, will not have been overly enamoured with Lukasz Fabianski’s goalkeeping for Bournemouth’s first goal that snuck inside the near post. Swansea’s first-team coach Alan Curtis, who again led the team in the absence of the Italian, said it would be a topic of discussion at Swansea’s Fairwood training ground on Monday. The visitors were sloppy at key times but one overwhelming positive was the performance of the Gambia winger Modou Barrow, who lit up an otherwise indifferent away performance. Barrow’s relentless energy went some way to compensate for the missing André Ayew, who is expected to return against Stoke next month after receiving treatment in France. Swansea remain eight points clear of the relegation zone but Curtis said it would be dangerous to consider them safe. “I would love to have 38 points,” he said, looking up the table at Bournemouth. “We need to get something from every game. We’re not only looking for safety, we’re looking to get as high as we possibly can, but safety has got to be the priority now, which means that the pressure now goes on to Saturday.” Man of the match Modou Barrow (Swansea)
